metadata.title: Isolation, sequence, infectivity and replication kinetics of SARS-CoV-2 1

abstract.text: SARS-CoV-2 emerged in December 2019 in Wuhan, China and has since infected over 1.5 25 million people, of which over 107,000 have died. As SARS-CoV-2 spreads across the planet, 26 speculations remain about the range of human cells that can be infected by SARS-CoV-2. In this 27 study, we report the isolation of SARS-CoV-2 from two cases of COVID-19 in Toronto, Canada. 28

We determined the genomic sequences of the two isolates and identified single nucleotide 29 changes in representative populations of our virus stocks. More importantly, we tested a wide 30 range of human immune cells for productive infection with SARS-CoV-2. Here we confirm that 31 human primary peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) are not permissive for SARS-CoV-32 2. As SARS-CoV-2 continues to spread globally, it is essential to monitor single nucleotide 33 polymorphisms in the virus and to continue to isolate circulating viruses to determine viral 34 genotype and phenotype using in vitro and in vivo infection models. 35

body_text.text: 6 Pellets were washed with distilled water and en-bloc stained with 2% uranyl acetate in distilled 116 water for 2 hrs. Pellets were washed with distilled water and dehydrated in an ethanol series. 117

Pellets were infiltrated with Embed 812/Araldite resin and cured at 65 degrees for 48 hrs. Resin 118 blocks were trimmed, polished and 90 nm thin sections were ultramicrotomed (Leica Reichert 119 Ultracut E, https://www.leica-microsystems.com) and mounted on TEM grids. Thin sections 120 were stained with 5% uranyl acetate and 5% lead citrate. Sections were imaged using 121

Transmission Electron Microscopy (ThermoFisher Scientific Talos L120C, 122 https://www.thermofisher.com) using a LaB6 filament at 120kV. 10 fields per cell type were 123 scanned. Each field was imaged with different magnifications at 2600x, 8500x, 17500x and 124 36000x. 125

To prepare cells for flowcytometry, 100µL (400,000 cells) of primary CD4 + , CD8 + , CD19 + and 127 monocytes were washed with 1 ml of phosphate buffered saline (PBS) and spun at 500 g for 5 128 minutes. The cells were resuspended in 100 µL of Live/Dead Violet (ThermoFisher Scientific, 129 https://www.thermofisher.com) as per manufacturer's recommendation and diluted 1:1000 in 130 PBS. Cells were incubated at 4°C for 30 minutes. Next, cells were washed with 1 ml of FACS 131 buffer (in-house reagent) and spun at 500 g for 5 minutes. Cells were then stained with 100 µL of 132 their respective stains (aCD4-FITC, aCD8-FITC, aCD19-FITC, aCD14-APC; Biolegend, 133 https://www.biolegend.com) at a concentration of 1µg/mL for 30 min at 4°C. After staining, the 134 cells were washed with 1mL of FACS Buffer and spun at 500 g for 5 minutes. Extra aliquots of 135 cells were left unstained, which were also spun at 500g for 5 minutes. The pellets were 136 resuspended in 100 µL of 1% paraformaldehyde (PFA; ThermoFisher Scientific, 137 https://www.thermofisher.com) and analyzed. Samples were run on the BD LSR Fortessa X20 138 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

Cells were gated on Live/Dead negative to exclude debris 139 and dead cells and were then gated on their respective cell surface markers to assess purity. 140 The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.11.037382 doi: bioRxiv preprint 9 ( Figure 1, panel A) . We collected 200 uL of cell culture supernatant and re-infected a fresh layer 185 of Vero E6 cells. Twenty-four hours post infection, both wells containing cells that were re-186 inoculated displayed extensive CPE (Figure 1, panel B) . We extracted viral RNA from the 187 supernatant and confirmed the presence of SARS-CoV-2 using a diagnostic real-time PCR assay 188 (qPCR; Figure 1 , panel C). We also confirmed the presence of coronavirus-like particles in 189 infected Vero E6 cells by electron microscopy (Figure 1, panel D) . 190 191 Next, we performed genome sequencing of both isolates, generating genome sequences with 192 7500-8000 fold coverage and ~94% completeness, with only ~260 bp and ~200 bp at the 5' and 193 3' termini undetermined (Table 1 ). Both shared synonymous and non-synonymous substitutions 194 with those independently observed in direct sequencing of clinical isolates (Table 1; In this study, we report the isolation of two replication competent SARS-CoV-2 isolates from 229 COVID-19 patients in Canada. We used TPCK-treated trypsin to enhance infection using clinical 230 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.04.11.037382 doi: bioRxiv preprint 11 specimens (Figure 1, panel A) . Exogenous trypsin activates SARS-CoV spike proteins more 231 efficiently and facilitates cellular entry (19). Exogenous trypsin treatment has also been shown to 232 enhance infectivity of other zoonotic bat-borne coronaviruses (20). Furthermore, TPCK-treated 233 trypsin was used to successfully isolate SARS-CoV-2 in China (1). In our studies, subsequent 234 infection and virus replication did not require any additional TPCK-treated trypsin (Figure 1,  235 panel B). The presence of CPE alone does not indicate the successful isolation of a coronavirus. 236

Mid-turbinate samples from adults with acute respiratory distress may often contain other 237 microbes, including viruses (21). Thus, to identify our isolates, we sequenced them to confirm 238 that they were reflective of SARS-CoV-2 isolates infecting patients worldwide, selecting SARS-239

CoV-2/SB3-TYAGNC for experimental investigation since this isolate produced less minority 240 sequencing reads (Table 1) -3 cells (8, 27, 28 ). In addition, 253 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF0.text: 167 amplification primer sequences removed using cutadapt (version 1.18) (11), and Illumina adapter 168 sequences were removed and low quality sequences trimmed or removed using Trimmomatic 169 (version 0.36) (12). Final sequence quality and confirmation of adapter/primer trimming were 170 confirmed by FASTQC (version 0.11.5) (13). SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences were assembled 171 using UniCycler (version 0.4.8; default settings, except for --mode conservative) (14) and 172 assembly statistics generated by QUAST (version 5.0.2) (15). Sequencing depth and 173 completeness of coverage of the assembled genomes was additionally assessed by Bowtie2 174 (version 2.3.4.1) (16) alignment of the sequencing reads against the assembled contigs and 175 statistics generated by ngsCAT (version 0.1) (17). Sequence variation in the assembled genomes 176 was assessed by BLASTN against SARS-CoV-2 genome sequences available in GenBank as 177 well as BreSeq (version 0.35.0) (18) analysis relative to GenBank entry MN908947.3 (first 178 genome sequence reported from the original Wuhan outbreak, China). 179 180 RESULTS 181 For virus isolation, we inoculated Vero E6 cells with the samples collected from mid-turbinate 182 swabs and monitored for cytopathic effects (CPE) daily. Seventy-two hours post infection (hpi), 183 cells inoculated with both samples displayed extensive CPE, relative to mock-inoculated cells 184 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF1.text: unpublished). SARS-CoV-2/SB2 additionally contained a non-synonymous 196 substitution at position 2832 (K856R in ORF1ab polyprotein) and three regions with mutations 197 or a deletion supported by a minority of sequencing reads, while SARS-CoV-2/SB3-TYAGNC 198 only had an additional synonymous substitution in ORF1ab polyprotein (Y925Y) plus a minority 199 of sequencing reads supporting another synonymous substitution in the ORF3a protein (I7I). As 200 such, SARS-CoV-2/SB3-TYAGNC was used for subsequent studies as best representative of a 201 clinical viral isolate. Raw sequencing reads for each isolate are available in NCBI BioProject 202 PRJNA624792. Only sequencing reads that aligned by Bowtie2 to the MN908947.3 SARS-CoV-203 2 genome were included in the deposited sequence files. 204 205 To determine the replication kinetics of SARS-CoV-2 in human structural and immune cells, we 206 infected Calu-3 (lung adenocarcinoma epithelial), THF (telomerase life extended human 207 S1) with a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.01. We monitored virus 211 replication over a period of 72 hours in the cell lines (Figure 2). We also determined virus 212 replication in PBMCs from healthy donors over a period of 48 hours (Figure 2). SARS-CoV-2 213 propagated to high titres in Vero E6 and Calu-3 cells (Figure 2). SARS-CoV-2 did not replicate 214 efficiently in THF cells (Figure 2). Interestingly, human immune cell lines and primary PBMCs 215 from healthy donors did not support SARS-CoV-2 replication (Figure 2) 216 217 To further support virus replication data, we imaged infected human epithelial, fibroblast and 218 immune cells using electron microscopy after 48 hrs of infection with SARS-CoV-2 at a MOI of 219 0.01 (Figure 3). We scanned 10 different fields per cell type, each using four different 220 magnifications of 2600x, 8500x, 17500x and 36000x to determine if the cell populations 221 contained virus-like particles. Virus-like particles were detected in 7/10 fields in Vero E6 cells 222 and 8/10 fields in Calu-3 cells (Figure 3, panels A and B). Interestingly, we also detected virus-223 like particles in 2/10 fields in primary CD4 + T cells (Figure 3, panel C). We did not observe any 224 virus-like particles in other human immune cells that were experimentally infected with SARS

FIGREF2.text: CoV caused the 2003-04 outbreak of SARS. SARS-CoV can infect structural (22) and 243 immune cell lines (23) from humans in vitro. We infected a range of human cell populations with 244 SARS-CoV-2/SB3-TYAGNC to identify cell types that can support productive infection of 245 SARS-CoV-2. Both Vero E6 and Calu-3 cells supported SARS-CoV-2 replication to high titres 246 (Figure 2), as reported in other recent studies (24, 25). Previously, SARS-CoV was also shown to 247 replicate efficiently in Vero E6 cells (22). Vero E6 cells are immunodeficient, with deficiencies 248 in innate antiviral interferon signaling, which makes them ideal candidates for virus isolation 249 (26). However, to enable studies on SARS-CoV-2-host interactions, it is important to identify 250 human lung epithelial cells with intact immune responses that can support SARS-CoV-2 251 replication. We and others have previously shown that SARS-CoV and Middle East respiratory 252 syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) replicate efficiently in Calu

FIGREF3.text: not support efficient replication of SARS-CoV-2 (24). Furthermore, hTERT life-257 extended human fibroblast cells (THF) also did not support virus replication (have shown that human immune cells, such as THP-1 cell lines are susceptible 260 to SARS-CoV infection (23). In our study, human immune cell populations, including THP-1-261 derived cell lines and primary cells (PBMCs) did not support productive SARS-CoV-2 262 replication (Figure 2). Interestingly, although primary CD4 + T cells did not support productive 263 virus replication, we observed virus-like particles in these cells by electron microscopy (Figure 264 3, panel C). This is consistent with a recent report by Wang and colleagues where they 265 demonstrated that human T cell lines are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 and pesudotyped viruses 266 (30). However, the study by Wang et al. did not quantify virus titres in the supernatant from 267 infected cells. In our study, we could not detect any replication competent virus in the 268 supernatant that was collected from SARS-CoV-2 infected CD4 + T cells (Figure 3). Human 269 immune cells lack expression of angiotensin converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) (31) 270 (https://www.proteinatlas.org), the functional receptor of SARS-CoV-2 (1, 32). Thus, although it 271 is intriguing that CD4 + T cells may be susceptible to SARS-CoV-2, our data show that these cells 272 are not permissive to SARS-CoV-2 replication in vitro. 273 274

FIGREF6.text: . Sequencing read and genome assembly statistics. Predicted mutations are relative to 429 the MN908947.3 SARS-CoV-2 genome (29,903 bp). Mutations within codons are underlined. 430 All mutations were predicted by 100% of sequencing reads mapping to that position, unless 431 otherwise noted. None of the mutations with support from less than 100% of sequencing reads 432 appeared in the final assembled genome consensus sequences. Substitutions in bold have been 433 observed in direct sequencing of patient isolates (Mubareka & McArthur, unpublished)

TABREF0.text: RNA was extracted from the supernatant of Vero E6 cells after 1 passage using the QIAamp 142 Viral RNA Mini kit (Qiagen, https://www.qiagen.com/us/) without addition of carrier RNA. 143 dsDNA for sequencing library preparation was synthesized using the Liverpool SARS-CoV-2 144 amplification protocol (10). Two 100 µM primer pools were prepared by combining primer pairs 145 in an alternating fashion to prevent amplification of overlapping regions in a single reaction.In a 146 PCR tube, 1µL Random Primer Mix (ProtoScript II First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit, New 147 England Biolabs, https://www.neb.ca) was added to 7 µL extracted RNA and denatured on 148 SimpliAmp thermal cycler (ThermoFisher Scientific, https://www.thermofisher.com) at 65°C for 149 5 min and then incubated on ice. 10 µL 2X ProtoScript II Reaction Mix and 2 µL 10X 150 ProtoScript II Enzyme Mix were then added to the denatured sample and cDNA synthesis 151 performed using the following conditions: 25°C for 5 min, 48°C for 15 min and 80°C for 5 min. 152 After cDNA synthesis, in a new PCR tube 2.5 µL cDNA was combined with 12.5 µL Q5 High-153 Fidelity 2X Master Mix (NEB, Ipswich, USA), 8.8 µL nuclease free water (ThermoFisher 154 Scientific, https://www.thermofisher.com), and 1.125 µL of 100 µM primer pool #1 or #2. PCR 155 cycling was then performed as follows: 98°C for 30 sec followed by 40 cycles of 98°C for 15 sec 156 All PCR reactions were purified using RNAClean XP (Beckman Coulter, 159 https://www.beckmancoulter.com) at 1.8x bead to amplicon ratio and eluted in 30 µL. 2 µL of 160 amplified material was quantified using a Qubit 1X dsDNA (ThermoFisher Scientific, 161 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. https://www.thermofisher.com) following the manufacturer's instructions. Illumina sequencing 162 libraries were prepared using Nextera DNA Flex Library Prep Kit and Nextera DNA CD Indexes 163 (Illumina, https://www.illumina.com) according to manufacturer's instructions. Paired-end 150 164 bp sequencing was performed for each library on a MiniSeq with the 300-cycle mid-output 165 reagent kit (Illumina, https://www.illumina.com), multiplexed with targeted sampling of ~40,000 166 clusters per library. Sequencing reads from pool #1 and pool #2 were combined (as R1 and R2),
